tool.name: PopToRaster
tool.summary: This tool converts a polygon feature class to an integer raster using the ObjectID of the feature class for the value of the output raster. This tool is based upon the "Polygon to Raster" conversion tool and is intended to be used for Dasymetric Mapping. The output raster will contain unique population source units and their associated population.

param.name: Population_Features

commandReference.para: The population input polygon featureclass to be converted to a raster.

dialogReference.para: The population input polygon featureclass to be converted to a raster.

param.pythonReference: The population input polygon featureclass to be converted to a raster.

param.name: Population_Count_Field

commandReference.para: Specify the field in the population dataset that contains count data.

dialogReference.para: Specify the field in the population dataset that contains count data.

param.pythonReference: Specify the field in the population dataset that contains count data.

param.name: Population_Key_Field

commandReference.para: Since the tool will always use the system-recognized ObjectID field for the output raster Values, this is for your reference only and is not used by the tool. It can be helpful to have another key field (commonly census FIPS code) for joining the output raster to other tables.

dialogReference.para: Since the tool will always use the system-recognized ObjectID field for the output raster Values, this is for your reference only and is not used by the tool. It can be helpful to have another key field (commonly census FIPS code) for joining the output raster to other tables.

param.pythonReference: Since the tool will always use the system-recognized ObjectID field for the output raster Values, this is for your reference only and is not used by the tool. It can be helpful to have another key field (commonly census FIPS code) for joining the outuput raster to other tables.

param.name: Ancillary_Raster

commandReference.para: The ancillary raster dataset to be used to redistribute population. The output raster from this tool will be snapped to the ancillary raster and have matching spatial reference and cell size.

dialogReference.para: The ancillary raster dataset to be used to redistribute population. The output raster from this tool will be snapped to the ancillary raster and have matching spatial reference and cell size.

param.pythonReference: The ancillary raster dataset to be used to redistribute population. The output raster from this tool will be snapped to the ancillary raster and have matching spatial reference and cell size.

param.name: Cell_Assignment_Type

commandReference.para: The method to determine how the cell will be assigned a value when more than one feature falls within a cell.
commandReference.bullet_item: CELL_CENTER—The polygon in which the center of the cell yields the attribute to assign to the cell.
MAXIMUM_AREA—The single feature with the largest area within the cell yields the attribute to assign to the cell.
MAXIMUM_COMBINED_AREA—Features with common attributes are combined to produce a single area within the cell in question for consideration when determining the largest area.

dialogReference.para: The method to determine how the cell will be assigned a value when more than one feature falls within a cell.
dialogReference.bullet_item: CELL_CENTER—The polygon in which the center of the cell yields the attribute to assign to the cell.
MAXIMUM_AREA—The single feature with the largest area within the cell yields the attribute to assign to the cell.
MAXIMUM_COMBINED_AREA—Features with common attributes are combined to produce a single area within the cell in question for consideration when determining the largest area.

param.pythonReference: The method to determine how the cell will be assigned a value when more than one feature falls within a cell.</P><LI>CELL_CENTER—The polygon in which the center of the cell yields the attribute to assign to the cell.</LI><LI>MAXIMUM_AREA—The single feature with the largest area within the cell yields the attribute to assign to the cell.</LI><LI>MAXIMUM_COMBINED_AREA—Features with common attributes are combined to produce a single area within the cell in question for consideration when determining the largest area.</LI>

param.name: Population_Raster

commandReference.para: The output population raster dataset that will be created, inlcuding the full path.
When you're not saving to a geodatabase, specify .tif for a TIFF file format, .img for an ERDAS IMAGINE file format, or no extension for a GRID file format.

dialogReference.para: The output population raster dataset that will be created, inlcuding the full path.
When you're not saving to a geodatabase, specify .tif for a TIFF file format, .img for an ERDAS IMAGINE file format, or no extension for a GRID file format.

param.pythonReference: The output population raster dataset that will be created, inlcuding the full path. When you're not saving to a geodatabase, specify .tif for a TIFF file format, .img for an ERDAS IMAGINE file format, or no extension for a GRID file format.

param.name: Population_Working_Table
param.dialogReference: The tool will create a standalone table for performing calcluations. Please enter a name and path for the output table.

tool.usage: We tried allowing the user to designate a field that would become the raster cell values, but found that ArcGIS handled this field differently depending on the formats of the input file and the output raster. Always using the field ArcGIS recognizes as the ObjectID field eliminated this inconsistency. A user may specify their own population key field, and this field will be included in the output population raster and population working table, but it will be included only for the convenience of the user, not for any functional part of the script. In this script the ancillary raster is used only to determine the spatial reference and cell size of the output population raster so that the two rasters are aligned when they are combined in the next script. In most cases the ancillary raster is a land-use or land-cover dataset. The cell assignment type is likely only relevant if the cell size is large relative to the population areal units, and any choice other than the default (Cell_Center) significantly adds to processing time. We have tested ESRI GRIDs and File Geodatabase Rasters most thoroughly as output formats, though other standalone raster formats should work as well. Problems tend to arise (if at all) when the attribute tables start to reach format limits. Please let us know if you experience problems.
tool.commandExample: PopToRaster C:\dasy\blkpop00.shp C:\dasy\lc01r CELL_CENTER C:\dasy\poprast C:\dasy\popworkingtable.dbf POP2000 FIPS

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This tool converts a polygon feature class to an integer raster using the ObjectID of the feature class for the value of the output raster. This tool is based upon the "Polygon to Raster" conversion tool and is intended to be used for Dasymetric Mapping. The output raster will contain unique population source units and their associated population.

Consts.useLimit: The author of this script assumes no liability for the quality nor the appropriate application of this code. Please make sure you fully understand the process before attempting to draw conclusions from the results.
